f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:11): I don't understand how people can argue that <sub> and <sup> are non-semantic.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:12): logic? we need that!?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:13): I mean, it seems to be just an objection to the name because it has a presentational meaning
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:13): though, the names have semantic meanings too
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (13:15): checks how those elements are defined in HTML5
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (13:16): what are people suggesting <sub> and <sup> be replaced with?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:17): it appears that <sup> and <sub> have several possible semantics
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:17): although meaning is likely to be altered more severely by removing them than removing <i> and <b>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:19): I think having catch all elements for several typograhpical conventions is a good a thing
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:20): it seems better than forcing use of <span> for everything
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:20): That such a typographical convention is used can be made clear in some media independent way and the user will know from the context what it was about.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:20): and better than inventing dozens of tags which might still not catch every case
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:21): notes that lynx renders 3<sup>2</sup> as 3^2
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:21): (Whether it was a mathematical formula or some chemical structure for instance. Or something like 2nd)
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (13:22): but not LaTeX ;)

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (13:27): "Semantics" as used outside markup languages is clearly not appropriate for HTML. We'd have thousands if not millions of silly elements and nobody who will ever implement them properly or support them

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:30): Some people seem to object that <sup> has too many possible meanings and a machine couldn't tell what you mean in a given context, but I think the value is that it indicates there's *some* kind of semantics and you can tell a human reader and they can work out what it means
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:30): and use xslt to convert it to html4 on the client side
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:31): whereas truly presentational elements don't have any meanings that a human could understand

73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (13:31): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yeah, just like when you're reading from paper, the fact that it is superscript and the context is enough to figure out what it means
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:31): I don't get how people can say <sup> is vague, while <em> isn't

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:35): If you wanted to write a web crawler that extracts mathematical expressions and evaluates them to analyse the frequency of miscalculations in published documents, then maybe you'd care about using some semantically-rich maths markup language; but I can't imagine many people doing that
